bestBHT.bht: They make confession that they know God, but in their works they deny Him. Their confession is a true one so far, that they have the knowledge, and belie it. He does not deny their theoretical knowledge of God, but that they practically know Him. They are abominable, disobedient, and for every good work worthless. By their works, they deny Him. Their conduct is such as to show that they have no real acquaintance with Him. They are reprobates, rejected as worthless when tested. Vice is a denial that we have any true knowledge of God. Their character, in respect to all that pertains to true piety, is to be disapproved by the truly pious, and will be by God at the last day.

Henry Alford: They make confession that they know God; but in their works they deny Him."
Being abominable, and disobedient, and for every good work worthless."
Their confession is a true one so far, that they have the knowledge, and belie it.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He does not deny their theoretical knowledge of God, but that they practically know Him.
Deny him—the opposite of the previous 'profess' or 'confess' Him.
Albert Barnes: They profess that they know God...But in works they deny him."
Their conduct is such as to show that they have no real acquaintance with him.

Are there none now who profess that they know God, but in works deny him; whose conduct is such that it ought to be abhorred; who are disobedient to the plain commands of God, and whose character in respect to all that pertains to true piety is to be disapproved by the truly pious, and will be by God at the last day?
Marvin Vincent: Not loudly and publicly profess (as Huther), but confess as opposed to deny (John 1:20); comp. Hebrews 11:13; Romans 10:9, Romans 10:10.
Abominable [βδελυκτοι] . N. T. o. Class. LXX, Proverbs 17:15; Sir. 41 5; 2 Macc. 1 27.
Reprobate [αδοκιμοι] . See on Romans 1:28; 1 Corinthians 9:27, and comp. 2 Timothy 3:8. The phrase reprobate unto every good work, N. T. o.
John Calvin: For hypocrites, who give their whole attention to minute observances, despise fearlessly what constitutes the chief part of the Christian life.
That their conduct is disgraceful and full of wickedness, and that not a spark of virtue is visible in their whole life.
They disapprove all that which claims their approbation and esteem; and are disaffected to all that good which the religion they profess would oblige them to the practice of.
Philip Schaff: Vice is a denial that we have any true knowledge of God.
Abominable, a strong word implying the disgust with which a pure mind contemplates certain sins.
Reprobates, or rejected after trial, a word of Paul's.
John Gill: They profess that they know God, yet this knowledge was but notional; it lay in theory and profession only; they had not a spiritual experimental knowledge of God in Christ.
They were not professed, but practical atheists; they owned there was a God, and boasted of their knowledge of him; but their lives and conversations showed that they had no true knowledge of him.
They were without Christ, and without his Spirit, and grace, without which no man can do anything that is spiritually good; they had no true faith, and therefore what they did was sinful.

bhtAttempts.bht: They make confession that they know God, but in their works they deny Him. Their confession is a true one so far, that they have the knowledge, and belie it. He does not deny their theoretical knowledge of God, but that they practically know Him. They are abominable, disobedient, and for every good work worthless. By their works, they deny Him. Their conduct is such as to show that they have no real acquaintance with Him. They are reprobates, rejected as worthless when tested. Vice is a denial that we have any true knowledge of God. Their character, in respect to all that pertains to true piety, is to be disapproved by the truly pious, and will be by God at the last day.

They confess to know God, but their actions deny Him. Their theoretical knowledge is not matched by practical knowledge, as they are abominable, disobedient, and worthless in their works. Their conduct shows a lack of real acquaintance with God. They are reprobates, rejected as worthless when tested. Vice is a denial of true knowledge of God. Their character, in relation to true piety, is disapproved by the truly pious and will ultimately be judged by God.

They confess to know God, but in their works, they deny Him. Their confession is true in that they possess knowledge, but their actions contradict their beliefs. They are abominable, disobedient, and their works are worthless. They lack a genuine understanding of God, as their conduct demonstrates. They are reprobates, rejected as worthless when tested. Vice is a denial of true knowledge of God. Their character, in relation to true piety, is disapproved by the truly pious and judged by God in the end.

They confess to know God, but in their works, they deny Him. Their confession is true in that they possess knowledge, but their actions contradict their beliefs. They are abominable, disobedient, and their works are worthless. They lack a genuine understanding of God, and their conduct demonstrates it. They are rejected as reprobates when tested. Their actions not only deny God but display a disregard for His teachings. Such behavior is abhorrent in the eyes of the truly pious and will face judgment from God.

They confess to know God, but their works deny Him. Their confession is true in theory, but their practical knowledge falls short. Their actions reflect their worthlessness, as they are abominable, disobedient, and lacking in good works. Their conduct reveals a lack of genuine acquaintance with God. They are reprobates, rejected as worthless when tested. Vice is a denial of true knowledge of God. Truly pious individuals disapprove of their character, and they will ultimately face judgment from God.
